title: I killed geth, then got "Last block not found." Can I recover?

body: It doesn't ignore Ctrl+C, it just needs to finish syncing the database. If you killed it mid sync... that's baaad :P

Ya, I figured. That's what I get for being impatient. :) 

Doing a resync now with your suggestions from another ticket. So far looks like it solves it.

Closing. This is not a direct issue.

tutut for doing a killall! ;-)

So I just got the same error, but only by pressing `Ctrl+C` (and waiting for it to shutdown properly). My logs got truncated by my next run of geth, so all that I can show you is what was saved in my terminal. Still, you can see the last thing geth did before croaking:

What's also interesting is another log I have running, one which greps the main output looking for the word "insert" (because downloading the chain just seems /so slow/ at times). Check out these block numbers:

That's the reason I pressed `Ctrl+C`, because it seemed like it was adding the same chain over and over again and getting nowhere. Either way, @obscuren, @karalabe, can you re-review?

> What's also interesting is another log I have running, one which greps the main output looking for the word "insert" (because downloading the chain just seems /so slow/ at times). Check out these block numbers:

Working on that. 

> greps the main output looking for the word "insert"

You probably want to grab `import` which actually tells you what it did
